questions.text: A 57-year-old multiparous woman comes to the physician because of urinary leakage for the past 6 months. She involuntarily loses a small amount of urine after experiencing a sudden, painful sensation in the bladder. She has difficulty making it to the bathroom in time and feels nervous when there is no bathroom nearby. She also started having to urinate at night. She does not have hematuria, abdominal pain, or pelvic pain. She has insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus and underwent surgical treatment for symptomatic pelvic organ prolapse 3 years ago. Menopause was 6 years ago, and she is not on hormone replacement therapy. She works as an administrative manager and drinks 3–4 cups of coffee daily at work. On physical examination, there is no suprapubic tenderness. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities and Q-tip test is negative. Ultrasound of the bladder shows a normal postvoid residual urine volume. Which of the following is the primary underlying cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Urge incontinence can result from detrusor muscle overactivity, which causes involuntary contraction of the detrusor muscle and urinary tenesmus that lead to a sudden release of urine. Anticholinergic agents (e.g., oxybutynin) can help treat this condition by decreasing detrusor muscle tone.

See “Overview of urinary incontinence” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence (due to impaired detrusor muscle contractility or bladder outlet obstruction) results in increased urine bladder volumes. Patients with overflow incontinence usually have continuous urinary leakage or dribbling (not sudden episodes of urinary loss), and postvoid residual urine volumes would be increased.

C) INCORRECT:

Trauma to the urinary tract (e.g., due to childbirth) can cause pelvic floor muscle weakening and urethral hypermobility so that the urethra and bladder neck cannot completely close against the anterior vaginal wall. As a result, increases in intraabdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, lifting), force urine through an incompletely closed urethra (stress incontinence). However, this patient has no evidence of stress incontinence (her Q-tip test is negative, has leakage of urine unrelated to coughing).

D) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infection can cause or worsen urinary incontinence (due to urethral irritation). Although infection should be ruled out in this patient, it is unlikely that this is the etiology of her incontinence, as she lacks any other signs of urinary tract infection (e.g., suprapubic tenderness, dysuria, hematuria).

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in postmenopausal women can result in atrophy of the urethral mucosal layers (e.g., decreased urethral mucosal seal, decreased urethral compliance, increased urethral irritation), all of which can contribute to incontinence. Although this patient's postmenopausal estrogen levels may be a contributing factor for her incontinence, her sudden urge to void with loss of urine suggests that urge incontinence is the primary etiology.

F) INCORRECT:

Excessive caffeine consumption can exacerbate the symptoms of urinary incontinence by increasing the volume of daily urine and irritating the bladder lining. Therefore, this patient should be advised to limit her caffeine consumption. However, caffeine consumption itself does not cause urinary incontinence.

G) INCORRECT:

Early-stage pelvic organ prolapse (POP) and stress incontinence often co-occur, as both can result from vaginal wall weakening. Since the patient underwent surgery for POP in the past, a recurrent POP is possible, but prolapse does not cause urinary incontinence itself. In fact, advanced stages of POP may be associated with improvements in incontinence due to kinking of the urethra. Importantly, POP is not associated with urge incontinence.

H) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence can result from decreased pelvic floor muscle tone in which the urethra and bladder neck cannot completely close against the anterior vaginal wall. As a result, increases in intraabdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, lifting) force urine through an incompletely closed urethra. Although this patient was likely suffering from decreased pelvic floor muscle tone before she underwent surgical treatment for symptomatic pelvic organ prolapse, she currently has no evidence of stress incontinence (her Q-tip test is negative, she has leakage of urine unrelated to coughing).
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent small volume voids. This condition can also cause nocturia, and be exacerbated by bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine).

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of loss of urine for the last several months. She loses small amounts of urine without warning after coughing or sneezing. She also sometimes forgets the names of her relatives. She is retired and lives at an assisted-living facility. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her older sister recently received a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include metformin and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. She walks without any problems. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Bacterial infection of the urinary tract

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Detrusor overactivity is an important cause of urge incontinence. This form of urinary incontinence is characterized by a strong, sudden urge to urinate, which results in involuntary leakage of urine. However, this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is not preceded by any urge to urinate.

B) INCORRECT:

Complete loss of sphincter function would cause total urinary incontinence, which is characterized by continuous urinary leakage with no associated preceding symptoms or specific trigger activity. Complete loss of sphincter function is unlikely in this patient, who exhibits urinary expulsion preceded by physical stress.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired detrusor contractility is the underlying mechanism of overflow incontinence, which is characterized by frequent, involuntary dribbling of urine that occurs when the bladder is full. Since this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress rather than a feeling of bladder fullness, this is unlikely to be the underlying cause here.

D) CORRECT:

Urethral hypermobility is one of the most common causes of stress incontinence and is caused by impaired support from the pelvic floor. At times of increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, coughing, sneezing), the proximal urethra and the bladder neck descend out of the pelvis and transmit more pressure to the bladder. During this process, intraurethral pressure falls below bladder pressure, resulting in urine leakage. Considering this patient's age and gender, urethral hypermobility can result from postmenopausal estrogen loss and as part of the normal aging process.

Treatment of stress incontinence includes lifestyle modifications, Kegel exercises, and insertion of a vaginal pessary. If conservative treatment is insufficient, pharmacological and surgical treatment can be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia is the underlying mechanism of reflex incontinence, which is characterized by unpredictable urinary leakage that occurs when the bladder is full or otherwise stimulated (e.g., by cold air). This occurs due to simultaneous dyssynergistic contractions of the sphincter and the detrusor muscle, brought about by an underlying neurologic condition like multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injury. This patient has no such condition and exhibits urinary expulsion that is preceded by physical stress.

F) INCORRECT:

A urinary tract infection could possibly cause incontinence. Preexisting diabetes mellitus, in the setting of forgetfulness (and thus, possibly poor personal hygiene), could increase the chance of infection in this patient. However, the lack of typical features of infection, like fever and dysuria, make this a highly unlikely underlying cause of this patient's condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Decreased cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) absorption is the underlying pathology in normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). This condition often manifests in adults > 60 years of age and commonly manifests with signs of dementia and urinary incontinence, which are both seen in this elderly patient. However, the absence of gait disturbance, which is typically the initial and most prominent symptom of the disease, makes this diagnosis unlikely. Also, the incontinence in NPH is usually of the urge type, in which the patient experiences a strong, sudden urge to urinate, followed by urinary leakage. Since this patient exhibits urinary expulsion that is not preceded by any urge to urinate, decreased CSF absorption is unlikely to be the underlying cause.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).
questions.hint: This patient presents with loss of urine with physical stress such as coughing, sneezing, and laughing. These features suggest a diagnosis of stress incontinence.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, is brought to the physician by staff of the nursing home where she resides because of involuntary loss of urine and increased frequency of urination over the past 2 weeks. She reports that she has very little time to get to the bathroom after feeling the urge to urinate. She says “accidents” have occurred 4–6 times a day during this period. She has never had urinary incontinence before. She has also been more tired than usual. She drinks 3 cups of coffee daily. Her last menstrual period was 25 years ago. She takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vagina and cervix; uterus and adnexa are small. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive coffee intake may also cause urinary urgency and frequency as caffeine causes rapid filling of the bladder. However, this patient's symptoms began 2 weeks ago and she does not report any significant changes in coffee consumption that would trigger this sudden onset. Therefore, caffeine cessation is unlikely to resolve her symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Application of estrogen cream is indicated in case of atrophic vaginitis that can also cause urinary incontinence. Atrophy may result in urethritis, loss of compliance, and possible irritation. While this patient is postmenopausal, she is missing further symptoms of vaginal atrophy such as vaginal dryness, irritation, and discomfort.

C) CORRECT:

Because urinary tract infection (UTI) is a common cause of acute urinary incontinence in elderly patients, urinalysis should be performed to screen for signs of infection. Urine culture is not always required but is indicated in patients with prolonged symptoms of UTI (> 7 days). Classic signs and symptoms of UTI, such as suprapubic pain and dysuria, are often absent in elderly patients, who can develop incontinence in addition to urgency and frequency. Reversible causes of urinary incontinence, including infections, medications (e.g., diuretics), and fecal impaction, should always be excluded before more invasive diagnostic testing is performed (e.g., urodynamic examination to measure bladder pressure and urethral closure pressure, cystoscopy to rule out tumors or fistulae).

D) INCORRECT:

A pad test may help identify the underlying cause of urinary incontinence. While a small loss of urine throughout the day may indicate stress incontinence, and a greater loss may indicate urge incontinence, this patient's symptoms point to an acute and reversible cause of incontinence that requires a different management approach.

E) INCORRECT:

A bladder stress test is performed in suspected stress incontinence that may manifest with leakage of urine associated with sneezing or coughing. However, a patient with stress incontinence is unlikely to have a history of irritative bladder symptoms such as urgency or frequency.

F) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic examination may help clarify the underlying mechanism in unclear cases of urinary incontinence and identify abnormalities such as urethral sphincter incompetence, reduced bladder compliance, detrusor instability, and low bladder capacity, all of which may cause urinary incontinence. Urodynamic examination is also performed prior to urinary tract surgery. However, before considering this investigation, another cheap and easily available diagnostic test for an acute and reversible cause of incontinence should be conducted.

G) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the pelvis may help to identify structural pelvic abnormalities that may also cause urinary incontinence, urgency, and frequency. This procedure is expensive and only considered as an additional diagnostic test if more basic investigations remain inconclusive.

H) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy allows visualization of the urethra and the entire bladder and may be helpful in identifying tumors, stones, or fistulae. Such structural abnormalities are rarely involved in the emergence of urinary incontinence. This patient's symptoms point to an acute and reversible cause of incontinence that requires a different management approach.
questions.hint: This elderly patient presents after the acute onset of urinary incontinence, urgency, and frequency, which suggests a possibly reversible cause of incontinence.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of loss of urinary control for the last year. The patient states that she loses control over her bladder when walking or standing up. She reports frequent, small-volume urine losses with no urge to urinate prior to the leakage. She tried to strengthen her pelvic muscles with supervised Kegel exercises and using a continence pessary but her symptoms did not improve. The patient is sexually active with her husband. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her hemoglobin A1c is 6.3% and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 100 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical vaginal estrogen is indicated in patients with vaginal atrophy, a common condition in postmenopausal women that may also manifest with symptoms of urinary incontinence. However, she is lacking typical signs of atrophy such as vaginal dryness, irritation, and dyspareunia.

B) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine is only used off-label for urinary stress incontinence; it is not yet approved in the US for this indication. Duloxetine is thought to enhance sphincter contraction as a result of inhibiting serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake at the spinal level.

C) INCORRECT:

Urethropexy (colposuspension) used to be the gold standard surgical procedure following unsuccessful conservative management of stress incontinence. However, it requires laparotomy or laparoscopy and is associated with a long operative duration and increased risk of certain postoperative complications (e.g., urgency incontinence). Urethropexy may be preferred in a patient who also requires repair of pelvic organ prolapse.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucosuria in poorly controlled diabetes mellitus may cause polyuria as glucose causes osmotic movement of water into the tubules. Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections that may cause unintentional voiding due to dysuria, frequency, and urgency. However, this patient's diabetes is well controlled and her loss of urine with light physical stress suggests stress incontinence.

E) INCORRECT:

Biofeedback is a supplemental modality for those learning pelvic floor muscle strengthening exercises with difficulty identifying the proper muscles. Sensors placed close to the anus are connected to a computer screen, displaying a graph with the patient's muscle contractions. While biofeedback may be helpful in regaining bladder control in urinary incontinence, this woman has already tried supervised muscle strengthening exercises, which did not relieve her symptoms.

F) CORRECT:

A urethral sling is the first-line surgical procedure for stress incontinence if conservative therapy, consisting of pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises), lifestyle changes (e.g., weight loss, alcohol cessation), and use of continence pessaries have failed. The sling is inserted via vaginal approach and supports and partially compresses the urethral lumen, thereby decreasing or stopping urinary leakage when intraabdominal pressure increases. Complications following the procedure include erosion of sling material with formation of fistulas, urinary obstruction (if the sling is too tense), damage to the bladder and bowel, pain, bleeding, and urinary tract infections.
questions.hint: This patient presents with loss of urine with light physical stress (walking and standing up), features which suggest moderate stress incontinence.

questions.text: Six hours after giving birth to a 4050-g (8-lb 15-oz) male infant, a 22-year-old primiparous woman experiences involuntary loss of urine. The urine loss occurs intermittently and there is no urge to urinate; it is not exacerbated by sneezing or coughing. Pregnancy was uncomplicated except for two urinary tract infections that were treated with nitrofurantoin. Delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and severe labor pains, and the patient received epidural analgesia. Her temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is distended and tender to deep palpation. Examination shows a uterus that extends to the umbilicus; there is copious, thick, blood-red vaginal discharge. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A vesicovaginal fistula can develop due to tissue trauma in complications of labor. Extended periods of tissue compression during prolonged labor restrict blood flow, and instruments used for operative vaginal delivery can cause lacerations, damaging the tissue between the vagina and bladder. When the tissue becomes necrotic, a fistula forms, manifesting with total incontinence. This patient's prolonged labor puts her at increased risk of developing a vesicovaginal fistula, but she shows no symptoms of this condition (e.g., continual leakage of urine from the vagina). Obstetric fistulas are uncommon in industrialized countries.
Image Description:

Urogenital fistulas are abnormal connections between the vagina and the urogenital system (e.g., vesicovaginal fistula). Urogenital fistulas can manifest with continuous urinary leakage from the vagina.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinary incontinence may occur as a manifestation of a urinary tract infection (UTI) secondary to irritation and sudden contraction of the bladder wall. While the likelihood of experiencing urinary incontinence increases with recurrent UTIs, this patient has no symptoms suggestive of a current UTI (e.g., urinary urgency, dysuria), and chronic urge incontinence is unlikely to develop after only two UTIs.

C) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural hematoma can develop as a complication of epidural anesthesia, which in turn can cause reflex incontinence by compressing the spinal cord. However, this patient has neither symptoms of reflex incontinence nor any associated neurological deficits (e.g., radicular back pain, paresis of the legs).

D) CORRECT:

Overdistention of the bladder can cause postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and overflow incontinence. Spinal anesthesia reduces bladder and internal sphincter contractility as well as the micturition reflex, leading to overfilling of the bladder. Additionally, perineal trauma or stretching during delivery can injure the pudendal nerve, resulting in increased distal motor latency and, consequently, delayed voluntary control of the external urethral sphincter. Intermittent catheterization is performed both to prevent overdistention of the bladder intrapartum and to treat PUR and overflow incontinence postpartum. Most cases of PUR resolve spontaneously.

In addition to spinal anesthesia, risk factors for PUR include operative vaginal delivery, episiotomy, and primiparity.

E) INCORRECT:

Intrinsic sphincter deficiency (ISD) is most commonly caused by neuromuscular damage to the pelvic floor, which is associated with factors such as macrosomia, forceps delivery, and rapid delivery of the fetal head in breech presentation. ISD usually affects women who have had multiple pelvic surgeries or vaginal deliveries, and it manifests with stress incontinence. This patient is primiparous and shows no signs of stress incontinence (e.g., positive bladder stress test).

F) INCORRECT:

Pelvic organ prolapse (POP) can occur as a complication of vaginal delivery and may cause overflow incontinence. However, POP is characterized by a feeling of vaginal fullness or pressure around the perineum. Moreover, POP more commonly affects women who have had multiple vaginal deliveries or traumatic births, and it manifests with urge or stress incontinence in the early stages. Overflow incontinence due to bladder outlet obstruction is usually only seen in advanced stages, which is unlikely in a patient without visible prolapse on pelvic examination.
questions.hint: This patient's involuntary loss of urine, abdominal distention, and tenderness after the administration of epidural analgesia for peripartal pain management suggest overflow incontinence. Blood-red vaginal discharge (lochia rubra) is a normal finding during the first 4 days after birth.

questions.text: A 60-year-old multiparous woman comes to the physician because of urinary leakage for the past 4 months. She involuntarily loses a small amount of urine after experiencing a sudden, painful sensation in the bladder. She wakes up at night several times to urinate, and she sometimes cannot make it to the bathroom in time. She has diabetes mellitus type 2 controlled with insulin and a history of pelvic organ prolapse, for which she underwent surgical treatment 5 years ago. Menopause was 11 years ago. She drinks 4-5 cups of coffee daily. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities, and a Q-tip test is negative. Ultrasound of the bladder shows a normal postvoid residual urine. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Early stage pelvic organ prolapse and stress incontinence often co-occur, as both can result from vaginal wall weakening. Since the patient underwent surgery for pelvic organ prolapse in the past, a recurrent pelvic organ prolapse is possible, but prolapse does not cause urinary incontinence in itself. In fact, advanced stages of pelvic organ prolapse may be associated with improvements in incontinence due to kinking of the urethra. Importantly, pelvic organ prolapse is not associated with urge incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence can result from decreased pelvic floor muscle tone in which the urethra and bladder neck cannot completely close against the anterior vaginal wall. As a result, increases in intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, lifting) force urine through an incompletely closed urethra. Although this patient was likely suffering from decreased pelvic floor muscle tone before she underwent surgical treatment for symptomatic pelvic organ prolapse, she currently has no evidence of stress incontinence (her Q-tip test is negative, has leakage of urine unrelated to coughing).

C) CORRECT:

Urge incontinence can result from increased detrusor muscle activity, which causes involuntary detrusor muscle contraction and urinary tenesmus that lead to a sudden release of urine. Antimuscarinic agents (e.g., oxybutynin) can help treat this condition by decreasing detrusor muscle tone.

D) INCORRECT:

Autonomic diabetic neuropathy can lead to an underactive detrusor that does not effectively contract enough to empty, resulting in overflow incontinence. Despite this patient's history of diabetes mellitus, overflow incontinence usually causes continuous urinary leakage or dribbling (not sudden episodes of urinary loss), and postvoid residual urine volumes would be increased.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive caffeine consumption can exacerbate the symptoms of urinary incontinence by increasing the volume of daily urine (due to the caffeine's diuretic effect) and irritating the bladder lining. Therefore, this patient should be advised to limit her caffeine consumption. However, caffeine consumption in itself does not cause urinary incontinence.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in postmenopausal women can result in atrophy of the urethral mucosal layers (e.g., decreased urethral mucosal seal, decreased urethral compliance, increased urethral irritation), all of which can contribute to incontinence. Although this patient's postmenopausal estrogen levels may be a contributing factor for her incontinence, her sudden urge to void with loss of urine suggests that urge incontinence is the primary etiology.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent small volume voids. This condition can also cause nocturia, and be exacerbated by bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine).

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of involuntary leakage of urine for the past 4 months, which she has experienced when bicycling to work and when laughing. She has not had any dysuria or urinary urgency. She has 4 children that were all delivered vaginally. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. The muscles most likely affected by this patient's condition receive efferent innervation from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The S1–S2 nerve roots give rise to the inferior gluteal nerve, which innervates the gluteus maximus muscle. Motor innervation to the piriformis muscle also originates from the same sacral roots. Both muscles are involved in hip extension and external rotation. Injury to the inferior gluteal nerve results in difficulty climbing stairs and getting up from a sitting position. It does not play a role in the development of stress incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

The superior gluteal nerve (from L4–S1) innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fascia latae muscles. These muscles are involved in abduction, internal rotation, and stabilization of the hip. An injury to the superior gluteal nerve results in Trendelenburg gait. It does not play a role in the development of stress incontinence.

C) INCORRECT:

The superior hypogastric plexus provides sympathetic innervation to the ovaries and ureter via the ovarian and ureteric plexus. It does not innervate the pelvic floor muscles or bladder neck, so its impairment does not cause stress incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

The obturator nerve (from L2–L4) provides motor innervation to the obturator externus, adductor longus, adductor brevis, gracilis, pectineus, and adductor magnus muscles and sensory innervation to the medial thigh. These muscles are involved in hip adduction. An injury to the obturator nerve results in loss of medial thigh sensation and hip adduction. It does not play a role in the development of stress incontinence.

E) CORRECT:

Somatic nerves arising from the S3–S4 spinal cord roots innervate the pelvic floor muscles (levator ani) and external urethral sphincter. The pudendal nerve, which originates from the S2–S4 spinal cord roots, innervates the external urethral sphincter and plays a role in maintaining continence. Stress incontinence is caused by impaired pelvic floor support, which can result from chronically elevated intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., due to a chronic cough, obesity) or from direct trauma to the levator ani muscle or nerve roots. Multiparous women are at a higher risk of such direct trauma, as it is usually caused by complications during delivery. Rarely, it can be caused by intrinsic sphincter defects resulting from scarring after surgery.

F) INCORRECT:

The ilioinguinal nerve (L1) provides sensory innervation to the anterior surface of the scrotum and root of the penis in men and the labia majora and mons pubis in women, as well as motor innervation to the internal oblique and transverse abdominal muscles. This nerve can be blocked with local anesthetics during inguinal hernia repair. It does not play a role in the development of stress incontinence.
questions.hint: Involuntary urinary leakage while exercising in a patient with a history of several vaginal deliveries is consistent with stress incontinence. The pelvic floor muscle group most commonly implicated in stress incontinence is the levator ani.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening urinary incontinence. She has started to wear incontinence pads because of frequent involuntary dribbling of urine that occurs even when resting. She has the sensation of a full bladder even after voiding. Her only medication is insulin. Physical examination shows a palpable suprapubic mass. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Urodynamic studies show an increased postvoid residual volume. Which of the following interventions is most likely to benefit this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic floor exercises can be used to treat underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence) and detrusor overactivity (urge incontinence). An increased postvoid residual volume would not be expected in a patient with an underactive bladder sphincter or an overactive bladder wall. Therefore, pelvic floor exercises would not be likely to alleviate this patient's urinary retention.

B) CORRECT:

Intermittent catheterization is indicated in patients with overflow incontinence. Overflow incontinence is caused by urinary retention, which can be a result of dysfunction of the bladder wall (e.g., underactive detrusor) or the sphincter (e.g., overactive urinary sphincter, benign prostatic hypertrophy). In a patient with diabetes mellitus, the most likely cause of urinary retention is an underactive bladder wall due to neuropathy of autonomic afferent nerve fibers, impairing the ability to sense bladder fullness and resulting in a decreased parasympathetic outflow. Other treatment options for overflow incontinence include behavioral changes (e.g., timed voiding, Valsalva maneuver to increase intravesical pressure), triggered voiding by stimulating sacral and lumbar dermatomes, or bethanechol, a muscarinic agonist that can stimulate detrusor contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

Prazosin, which causes relaxation of the internal urethral sphincter via alpha-1 receptor antagonism, is used to treat overflow incontinence due to an overactive sphincter or benign prostatic hyperplasia. This patient has urinary retention and overflow incontinence, but the most likely cause is an underactive bladder wall due to diabetic neuropathy of the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that innervate the bladder wall rather than an overactive sphincter. Therefore, prazosin is unlikely to be effective in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A vaginal pessary would elevate the bladder neck angle and compress the urethra against the pubic symphysis. Vaginal pessaries are used in the treatment of underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence). This patient has diabetes, a predisposing factor for stress incontinence. Diabetes may cause neuropathy of the pudendal nerve or the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that innervate the sphincter. However, stress incontinence would cause dribbling of urine when laughing or coughing. The use of a vaginal pessary might worsen urinary retention in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine, which is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, is used in the treatment of underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence) because increased noradrenergic and serotonergic activity in the sacral spinal cord can increase external urethral sphincter activity. This patient has diabetes, a predisposing factor for stress incontinence. Diabetes may cause neuropathy of the pudendal nerve or the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that innervate the sphincter. However, stress incontinence would cause dribbling of urine when laughing or coughing. Duloxetine therapy might worsen urinary retention in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Oxybutynin, which relaxes the detrusor muscle via M3 receptor antagonism, is used to treat detrusor overactivity (urge incontinence). Patients with urge incontinence have a sudden urge to urinate and are often unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. An increased postvoid residual urine volume (bladder retention) would not be expected in a patient with urge incontinence. In this patient with urinary retention due to detrusor underactivity, oxybutynin would most likely worsen their symptoms.
questions.hint: In a patient with a distended bladder, involuntary dribbling of urine and increased postvoid residual volume indicate overflow incontinence.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she sustained a spinal cord injury and pelvic fracture following a motorcycle accident. She undergoes surgery and is transferred to the rehabilitation unit for therapy. During her rehabilitation, she notices frequent dribbling of urine despite the absence of an urge to urinate. She is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2/5 muscle strength in the bilateral lower extremities, decreased sensation in the lower extremities, decreased rectal tone, and a palpable suprapubic mass. Genital examination shows no abnormalities. Straight intermittent catheterization is performed and she no longer dribbles urine for the next few hours. Urinalysis shows negative leukocyte esterase and negative nitrites. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urethral hypermobility can cause stress incontinence, especially in women. Urethral hypermobility can occur in patients with pelvic fractures and/or following pelvic surgery due to damage to the pelvic floor muscles. However, stress incontinence is characterized by urinary leakage during activities that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising).

B) CORRECT:

Underactivity of the detrusor muscle is one of the causes of overflow incontinence. Patients with an acute spinal cord injury (SCI) can have spinal shock, which is a combination of decreased sensation, flaccid paralysis, and autonomic dysfunction below the level of an SCI. Autonomic dysfunction results in parasympathetic inactivation and a consequent atonic bladder. Patients with SCI become unaware of bladder filling and feel no urge to void, resulting in an overfilled and overdistended bladder that is palpable in the suprapubic region. When intravesical pressure rises above bladder outlet resistance, involuntary dribbling of urine occurs. SCI at or below the sacral micturition center can also cause overflow incontinence due to damage to the lower motor neurons that form part of the micturition reflex arc. Urinary retention in patients with an atonic bladder is best managed by clean intermittent catheterization.

Another cause of overflow incontinence is bladder outflow obstruction (e.g., benign prostatic hyperplasia in men or pelvic organ prolapse and uterine fibroids in women). Bladder outlet obstruction is often associated with hesitancy and a sensation of incomplete emptying.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased bladder sensitivity results from overactivity of the detrusor muscle, which causes urge incontinence. Urge incontinence is characterized by a strong urge to void that usually precedes or accompanies urine leakage.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrinsic sphincteric deficiency can cause stress incontinence, and it can occur in patients with pelvic fractures and/or following pelvic surgery. However, stress incontinence is characterized by urinary leakage during activities that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising).

E) INCORRECT:

Complete loss of sphincter function can cause total incontinence, which can result from a spinal cord injury and manifest with involuntary urine loss without an urge to urinate. This patient's urinary incontinence, however, only occurs when her bladder is full (she no longer dribbles urine for a few hours after catheterization), whereas total incontinence is characterized by continuous urinary leakage.
questions.hint: A history of intermittent dribbling of urine not associated with increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising) or an urge to urinate is suggestive of overflow incontinence.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 4, comes to the physician for evaluation of urinary incontinence. She emigrated from Ethiopia with her family 6 months ago. She has had intermittent, painless involuntary urine leakage for many years. Her urinary incontinence worsened following the delivery of her last child. She describes the birth as having been “very difficult.” She says that she does not feel that her bladder is full. Since her early 20s, she has had multiple episodes of vaginal infections for which she received over-the-counter antibiotics. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Her older sister and mother had urinary incontinence starting in their mid-30s. The patient is currently not sexually active. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Pelvic examination discloses a nontender scar in the anterior portion of the vagina. A double dye test shows pooling of dyed fluid in the vagina. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Family history is a risk factor for urge incontinence, which is typically associated with detrusor overactivity and manifests with involuntary leakage of urine. However, this patient's urinary incontinence is most likely due to a vesicovaginal fistula, which is not associated with a genetic predisposition. Vesicovaginal fistulas have a high prevalence in resource-limited countries, which could explain this patient's family history of urinary incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can develop in a patient with a history of multiple vaginal infections. PID can also manifest with urinary symptoms if the bladder is involved. However, most patients with PID and bladder involvement develop symptoms of cystitis (e.g., urinary frequency, dysuria) rather than urinary incontinence. This patient's symptoms are most like due to a vesicovaginal fistula. Although PID can cause fistula formation in severe cases, it typically affects the upper reproductive female tract (e.g., uterus, ovaries) rather than the vagina.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeated stretching of the pelvic floor muscles from childbirth in multiparous women can cause urethral hypermobility and manifest with stress incontinence. However, this patient's urinary incontinence is most likely due to a vesicovaginal fistula, for which multiparity is not a risk factor.

D) INCORRECT:

Obesity is an important risk factor for urinary stress incontinence, which typically manifests with intermittent involuntary leakage of urine. However, this patient's urinary incontinence is most likely due to a vesicovaginal fistula, for which obesity is not a risk factor.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus is a risk factor for recurrent urinary tract infections, which can manifest with urge incontinence. However, this patient's urinary incontinence is most likely due to a vesicovaginal fistula, for which diabetes mellitus is not a risk factor.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's vesicovaginal fistula is most likely a result of her previous obstructed labor. The obstructed fetal head exerts pressure on the pelvic bones and causes pressure necrosis of the vaginal wall and bladder, which can result in fistula formation. Vesicovaginal fistulas are most commonly seen in individuals from resource-limited countries, where there is limited access to emergency obstetric care. In contrast, vesicovaginal fistulas in women from resource-rich countries are usually a result of iatrogenic injury (e.g., bladder injury during a hysterectomy). The diagnosis is confirmed with a double dye test, which is positive when a tampon inserted into the vagina stains blue after the bladder is filled with methylene blue. The mainstay of treatment for vesicovaginal fistulas is surgical repair.
questions.hint: This patient's history of multiple vaginal infections, persistent urinary incontinence that worsened after a difficult delivery, a scar on the anterior vaginal wall, and a positive double dye test are consistent with a vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old woman presents for evaluation of urinary symptoms. She has a 6- to 8-month history of a strong urge to urinate and occasional leakage of urine before she can get to the bathroom. Her neurologic examination is unremarkable. Pelvic examination shows no evidence of mass or prolapse. Her BMI is 36. A urinalysis is normal.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Ask the patient to complete a voiding diary
Schedule transvaginal ultrasonography of the pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic studies are invasive tests that simulate the filling and emptying phases of micturition to assess for detrusor overactivity, bladder outlet obstruction, and detrusor sphincter dyssynergia. Given the invasive nature of this testing, it is not considered an appropriate study for initial evaluation of patients who present with urge urinary incontinence and overactive bladder symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring the post-void residual urine is not indicated in this patient, given the absence of obstructive urinary symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

A common symptom of overactive bladder is urge urinary incontinence (UUI), as described in this case. Evaluating a patient with suspected UUI requires taking a complete history, conducting neurologic and pelvic examinations as part of the physical examination, and ordering a urinalysis. The next step is to then evaluate both subjective (patient-reported) and objective (bladder or voiding diary) outcomes, to assess the severity of the symptoms.

A voiding diary can help to quantify the patient's voiding and incontinence episodes, which can be useful for both the clinician and the patient. During the initial evaluation phase, the diary provides information that can help the clinician plan appropriate components of intervention, particularly behavioral intervention. Recording the times that the patient voids provides a foundation for determining voiding intervals in bladder training programs. The diary can also be used during the course of treatment to track the effectiveness of various treatment components and guide the intervention. Completing the diary can also help enhance patients' awareness of their voiding habits and help them recognize activities that trigger their incontinence.

Key learning point: The first step in evaluating a woman with urge urinary incontinence, no obstructive symptoms, and a normal physical examination and urinalysis is to ask her to complete a voiding diary.

D) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic therapy is not appropriate until precipitating factors are identified and remediated when possible.

E) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the pelvis is not warranted in this patient, given her normal findings on physical examination.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman reports a one-year history of progressive urinary incontinence that occurs during coughing, sneezing, and laughing. It has had a noticeable effect on her quality of life during the past 2 months.
She has been postmenopausal for the past 10 years. Her medical history includes only a traumatic arm fracture and four full-term vaginal deliveries. She does not use tobacco, she drinks alcohol socially, and she exercises regularly. A physical examination is unremarkable, although there is thinning, pallor, and loss of rugae in the vaginal wall.
Which one of the following tests is the most appropriate initial evaluation for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of the urinary flow rate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although low estrogen levels may contribute indirectly to the development of postmenopausal urinary incontinence, measuring estrogen levels has no diagnostic value in the evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Scanning of the bladder, including the postvoid residual urinary volume, has limited diagnostic value in the initial evaluation and is not recommended for the routine evaluation of women with symptoms of incontinence. Such scanning is necessary before invasive anti-incontinence surgery or if there is a question of overflow incontinence caused by bladder-outlet obstruction, which is unlikely in a woman.

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring peak urine flow (the urinary flow rate) is not recommended in women.

D) CORRECT:

Urinary incontinence is a common condition, affecting millions of women. The majority of presentations can be characterized as stress, urge, or mixed-type urinary incontinence. Stress urinary incontinence manifests as leakage of urine in the presence of increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during coughing or laughing. It is most commonly caused by a weak pelvic floor, often after several vaginal deliveries.

The first and easiest test in evaluating urinary incontinence is urinalysis, to rule out a urinary tract infection. Although asymptomatic bacteriuria does not cause urinary incontinence, increasing incontinence may be the only presenting symptom of a urinary tract infection.

Key learning point: In a woman with urinary leakage and other symptoms of stress urinary incontinence, the initial diagnostic test should be urinalysis, to rule out a urinary tract infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Routine urodynamic testing is not recommended to evaluate urinary incontinence. Urodynamic studies are invasive and expensive, require special equipment and training, are not usually necessary to make a diagnosis, and have not been found to affect outcomes in this situation. Urodynamic studies are helpful in the workup of neurogenic bladder.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to the office because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening urinary incontinence. She has started to wear incontinence pads because of frequent involuntary dribbling of urine that occurs even when resting. She has the sensation of a full bladder even after voiding. Her only medication is insulin. Physical examination shows a palpable suprapubic mass. Urodynamic studies show an increased postvoid residual volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oxybutynin, which relaxes the detrusor muscle via M3 receptor antagonism, is used to treat detrusor overactivity (urge incontinence). Patients with urge incontinence have a sudden urge to urinate and are often unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. An increased postvoid residual urine volume (bladder retention) would not be expected in a patient with urge incontinence. In this patient with urinary retention due to detrusor underactivity, oxybutynin would most likely worsen their symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Intermittent catheterization is indicated in patients with overflow incontinence. Overflow incontinence is caused by urinary retention, which can be a result of dysfunction of the bladder wall (e.g., underactive detrusor) or the sphincter (e.g., overactive urinary sphincter, benign prostatic hypertrophy). In a patient with diabetes mellitus, the most likely cause of urinary retention is an underactive bladder wall due to neuropathy of autonomic afferent nerve fibers, impairing the ability to sense bladder fullness and resulting in a decreased parasympathetic outflow. Other treatment options for overflow incontinence include behavioral changes (e.g., timed voiding, Valsalva maneuver to increase intravesical pressure), triggered voiding by stimulating sacral and lumbar dermatomes, or bethanechol, a muscarinic agonist that can stimulate detrusor contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic floor exercises can be used to treat underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence) and detrusor overactivity (urge incontinence). An increased postvoid residual volume would not be expected in a patient with an underactive bladder sphincter or an overactive bladder wall. Therefore, pelvic floor exercises would not be likely to alleviate this patient's urinary retention.

D) INCORRECT:

A vaginal pessary would elevate the bladder neck angle and compress the urethra against the pubic symphysis. Vaginal pessaries are used in the treatment of underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence). This patient has diabetes, a predisposing factor for stress incontinence. Diabetes may cause neuropathy of the pudendal nerve or the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that innervate the sphincter. However, stress incontinence would cause dribbling of urine when laughing or coughing. The use of a vaginal pessary might worsen urinary retention in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine, which is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, is used in the treatment of underactive urethral sphincters (stress incontinence) because increased noradrenergic and serotonergic activity in the sacral spinal cord can increase external urethral sphincter activity. This patient has diabetes, a predisposing factor for stress incontinence. Diabetes may cause neuropathy of the pudendal nerve or the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that innervate the sphincter. However, stress incontinence would cause dribbling of urine when laughing or coughing. Duloxetine therapy might worsen urinary retention in this patient.
questions.hint: In a patient with a distended bladder, involuntary dribbling of urine and increased postvoid residual volume indicate overflow incontinence.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the office because of urinary leakage for the past 6 months. She involuntarily loses a small amount of urine after experiencing a sudden, painful sensation in the bladder. She has difficulty making it to the bathroom in time and has started having to urinate at night. She does not have hematuria, abdominal pain, or pelvic pain. Menopause was 6 years ago. She drinks 3–4 cups of coffee daily at work. On physical examination, there are no abnormalities and Q-tip test is negative. Ultrasound of the bladder shows a normal postvoid residual urine volume. Which of the following is the primary underlying cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Urge incontinence can result from detrusor muscle overactivity, which causes involuntary contraction of the detrusor muscle and urinary tenesmus that lead to a sudden release of urine. Anticholinergic agents (e.g., oxybutynin) can help treat this condition by decreasing detrusor muscle tone.

See “Overview of urinary incontinence” table.

Key learning point: Urge incontinence is primarily caused by increased detrusor muscle activity, leading to involuntary bladder contractions and sudden urinary urgency.

B) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence (due to impaired detrusor muscle contractility or bladder outlet obstruction) results in increased urine bladder volumes. Patients with overflow incontinence usually have continuous urinary leakage or dribbling (not sudden episodes of urinary loss), and postvoid residual urine volumes would be increased.

C) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infection can cause or worsen urinary incontinence (due to urethral irritation). Although infection should be ruled out in this patient, it is unlikely that this is the etiology of her incontinence, as she lacks any other signs of urinary tract infection (e.g., suprapubic tenderness, dysuria, hematuria).

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased estrogen levels in postmenopausal women can result in atrophy of the urethral mucosal layers (e.g., decreased urethral mucosal seal, decreased urethral compliance, increased urethral irritation), all of which can contribute to incontinence. Although this patient's postmenopausal estrogen levels may be a contributing factor for her incontinence, her sudden urge to void with loss of urine suggests that urge incontinence is the primary etiology.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive caffeine consumption can exacerbate the symptoms of urinary incontinence by increasing the volume of daily urine and irritating the bladder lining. Therefore, this patient should be advised to limit her caffeine consumption. However, caffeine consumption itself does not cause urinary incontinence.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has urge incontinence, as evidenced by her sudden urge to urinate resulting in frequent small volume voids. This condition can also cause nocturia, and be exacerbated by bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine).

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the office by staff of the nursing home where she resides because of involuntary loss of urine and increased frequency of urination over the past 2 weeks. She reports that she has very little time to get to the bathroom after feeling the urge to urinate. She says “accidents” have occurred 4–6 times a day during this period. She drinks 3 cups of coffee daily. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vagina and cervix; uterus and adnexa are small. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive coffee intake may also cause urinary urgency and frequency as caffeine causes rapid filling of the bladder. However, this patient's symptoms began 2 weeks ago and she does not report any significant changes in coffee consumption that would trigger this sudden onset. Therefore, caffeine cessation is unlikely to resolve her symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Because urinary tract infection (UTI) is a common cause of acute urinary incontinence in elderly patients, urinalysis should be performed to screen for signs of infection. Urine culture is not always required but is indicated in patients with prolonged symptoms of UTI (> 7 days). Classic signs and symptoms of UTI, such as suprapubic pain and dysuria, are often absent in elderly patients, who can develop incontinence in addition to urgency and frequency. Reversible causes of urinary incontinence, including infections, medications (e.g., diuretics), and fecal impaction, should always be excluded before more invasive diagnostic testing is performed (e.g., urodynamic examination to measure bladder pressure and urethral closure pressure, cystoscopy to rule out tumors or fistulae).

C) INCORRECT:

A bladder stress test is performed in suspected stress incontinence that may manifest with leakage of urine associated with sneezing or coughing. However, a patient with stress incontinence is unlikely to have a history of irritative bladder symptoms such as urgency or frequency.

D) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic examination may help clarify the underlying mechanism in unclear cases of urinary incontinence and identify abnormalities such as urethral sphincter incompetence, reduced bladder compliance, detrusor instability, and low bladder capacity, all of which may cause urinary incontinence. Urodynamic examination is also performed prior to urinary tract surgery. However, before considering this investigation, another cheap and easily available diagnostic test for an acute and reversible cause of incontinence should be conducted.

E) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the pelvis may help to identify structural pelvic abnormalities that may also cause urinary incontinence, urgency, and frequency. This procedure is expensive and only considered as an additional diagnostic test if more basic investigations remain inconclusive.
questions.hint: This elderly patient presents after the acute onset of urinary incontinence, urgency, and frequency, which suggests a possibly reversible cause of incontinence.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents for evaluation of urinary symptoms. She has a 6- to 8-month history of a strong urge to urinate and occasional leakage of urine before she can get to the bathroom. Her neurologic examination is unremarkable. Pelvic examination shows no evidence of mass or prolapse. Her BMI is 36. A urinalysis is normal. Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Ask the patient to complete a voiding diary
Schedule transvaginal ultrasonography of the pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic studies are invasive tests that simulate the filling and emptying phases of micturition to assess for detrusor overactivity, bladder outlet obstruction, and detrusor sphincter dyssynergia. Given the invasive nature of this testing, it is not considered an appropriate study for initial evaluation of patients who present with UUI and OAB symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring the post-void residual urine is not indicated in this patient, given the absence of obstructive urinary symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

A common symptom of overactive bladder is urge urinary incontinence (UUI), as described in this case. Evaluating a patient with suspected UUI requires taking a complete history, conducting neurologic and pelvic examinations as part of the physical examination, and ordering a urinalysis. The next step is to then evaluate both subjective (patient-reported) and objective (bladder or voiding diary) outcomes, to assess the severity of the symptoms. A voiding diary can help to quantify the patient's voiding and incontinence episodes, which can be useful for both the clinician and the patient. Recording the times that the patient voids provides a foundation for determining voiding intervals in bladder training programs.

Key learning point: The first step in evaluating a woman with urge urinary incontinence, no obstructive symptoms, and a normal physical examination and urinalysis is to ask her to complete a voiding diary.

D) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic therapy is not appropriate until precipitating factors are identified and remediated when possible.

E) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the pelvis is not warranted in this patient, given her normal findings on physical examination.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman reports a 6-month history of daily urinary incontinence that occurs after coughing, sneezing, and laughing. She does not report any urinary urgency, increased urinary frequency, changes in the color or smell of the urine, or fecal incontinence. She has had three pregnancies, each with a vaginal delivery, and her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. Her BMI is 22. Abdominal and pelvic examinations are normal. Urinalysis shows no evidence of a urinary tract infection. The residual urinary volume after voiding is within the normal range. What is the most appropriate initial treatment of this patient’s urinary incontinence?

choices.text: Initiation of hormone-replacement therapy with a combination of estrogen and progesterone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hormone-replacement therapy has been associated with an increased incidence of stress urinary incontinence and is thus not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Stress urinary incontinence refers to involuntary leakage of urine that happens with increased abdominal pressure (as occurs during coughing, laughing, and sneezing), leading to increased bladder pressure that exceeds urethral resistance. Risk factors include middle age (peak incidence at 45–49 years), multiple pregnancies with vaginal delivery, and obesity. After urinary tract infection and urinary retention (overflow incontinence) are ruled out, first-line treatment consists of pelvic-floor muscle training (commonly known as Kegel exercises) and incontinence pessaries. Pelvic-floor exercises (30–50 contractions of the pelvic-floor muscles each day) are often the preferred initial strategy for patients interested in pursuing therapy that is less invasive than surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for stress urinary incontinence in women is a regimen of pelvic-floor exercises.

C) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine hydrochloride is not approved for stress urinary incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

Urethral bulking agents are a surgical treatment option for stress urinary incontinence, but they are not the first-line treatment option.

E) INCORRECT:

Tolterodine is used to treat urge incontinence.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she sustained a spinal cord injury and pelvic fracture. She undergoes surgery and is transferred to the rehabilitation unit for therapy. During her rehabilitation, she notices frequent dribbling of urine despite the absence of an urge to urinate. Physical examination shows 2/5 muscle strength in the bilateral lower extremities, decreased sensation in the lower extremities, decreased rectal tone, and a palpable suprapubic mass. Straight intermittent catheterization is performed and she no longer dribbles urine for the next few hours. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urethral hypermobility can cause stress incontinence, especially in women. Urethral hypermobility can occur in patients with pelvic fractures and/or following pelvic surgery due to damage to the pelvic floor muscles. However, stress incontinence is characterized by urinary leakage during activities that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising).

B) CORRECT:

Underactivity of the detrusor muscle is one of the causes of overflow incontinence. Patients with an acute spinal cord injury (SCI) can have spinal shock, which is a combination of decreased sensation, flaccid paralysis, and autonomic dysfunction below the level of an SCI. Autonomic dysfunction results in parasympathetic inactivation and a consequent atonic bladder. Patients with SCI become unaware of bladder filling and feel no urge to void, resulting in an overfilled and overdistended bladder that is palpable in the suprapubic region. When intravesical pressure rises above bladder outlet resistance, involuntary dribbling of urine occurs. SCI at or below the sacral micturition center can also cause overflow incontinence due to damage to the lower motor neurons that form part of the micturition reflex arc. Urinary retention in patients with an atonic bladder is best managed by clean intermittent catheterization.

Another cause of overflow incontinence is bladder outflow obstruction (e.g., benign prostatic hyperplasia in men or pelvic organ prolapse and uterine fibroids in women). Bladder outlet obstruction is often associated with hesitancy and a sensation of incomplete emptying.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased bladder sensitivity results from overactivity of the detrusor muscle, which causes urge incontinence. Urge incontinence is characterized by a strong urge to void that usually precedes or accompanies urine leakage.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrinsic sphincteric deficiency can cause stress incontinence, and it can occur in patients with pelvic fractures and/or following pelvic surgery. However, stress incontinence is characterized by urinary leakage during activities that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising).

E) INCORRECT:

Complete loss of sphincter function can cause total incontinence, which can result from a spinal cord injury and manifest with involuntary urine loss without an urge to urinate. This patient's urinary incontinence, however, only occurs when her bladder is full (she no longer dribbles urine for a few hours after catheterization), whereas total incontinence is characterized by continuous urinary leakage.
questions.hint: A history of intermittent dribbling of urine not associated with increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing, exercising) or an urge to urinate is suggestive of overflow incontinence.

questions.text: Six hours after giving birth to a 4050-g (8-lb 15-oz) male infant, a 22-year-old primiparous woman experiences involuntary loss of urine. The urine loss occurs intermittently and there is no urge to urinate; it is not exacerbated by sneezing or coughing. Delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and severe labor pains, and the patient received epidural analgesia. Temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is distended and tender to deep palpation. Examination shows a uterus that extends to the umbilicus; there is copious, thick, blood-red vaginal discharge. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A vesicovaginal fistula can develop due to tissue trauma in complications of labor. Extended periods of tissue compression during prolonged labor restrict blood flow, and instruments used for operative vaginal delivery can cause lacerations, damaging the tissue between the vagina and bladder. When the tissue becomes necrotic, a fistula forms, manifesting with total incontinence. This patient's prolonged labor puts her at increased risk of developing a vesicovaginal fistula, but she shows no symptoms of this condition (e.g., continual leakage of urine from the vagina). Obstetric fistulas are uncommon in industrialized countries.
Image Description:

Urogenital fistulas are abnormal connections between the vagina and the urogenital system (e.g., vesicovaginal fistula). Urogenital fistulas can manifest with continuous urinary leakage from the vagina.

B) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural hematoma can develop as a complication of epidural anesthesia, which in turn can cause reflex incontinence by compressing the spinal cord. However, this patient has neither symptoms of reflex incontinence nor any associated neurological deficits (e.g., radicular back pain, paresis of the legs).

C) CORRECT:

Overdistention of the bladder can cause postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and overflow incontinence. Spinal anesthesia reduces bladder and internal sphincter contractility as well as the micturition reflex, leading to overfilling of the bladder. Additionally, perineal trauma or stretching during delivery can injure the pudendal nerve, resulting in increased distal motor latency and, consequently, delayed voluntary control of the external urethral sphincter. Intermittent catheterization is performed both to prevent overdistention of the bladder intrapartum and to treat PUR and overflow incontinence postpartum. Most cases of PUR resolve spontaneously.

In addition to spinal anesthesia, risk factors for PUR include operative vaginal delivery, episiotomy, and primiparity.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrinsic sphincter deficiency (ISD) is most commonly caused by neuromuscular damage to the pelvic floor, which is associated with factors such as macrosomia, forceps delivery, and rapid delivery of the fetal head in breech presentation. ISD usually affects women who have had multiple pelvic surgeries or vaginal deliveries, and it manifests with stress incontinence. This patient is primiparous and shows no signs of stress incontinence (e.g., positive bladder stress test).

E) INCORRECT:

Pelvic organ prolapse (POP) can occur as a complication of vaginal delivery and may cause overflow incontinence. However, POP is characterized by a feeling of vaginal fullness or pressure around the perineum. Moreover, POP more commonly affects women who have had multiple vaginal deliveries or traumatic births, and it manifests with urge or stress incontinence in the early stages. Overflow incontinence due to bladder outlet obstruction is usually only seen in advanced stages, which is unlikely in a patient without visible prolapse on pelvic examination.
questions.hint: This patient's involuntary loss of urine, abdominal distention, and tenderness after the administration of epidural analgesia for peripartal pain management suggest overflow incontinence. Blood-red vaginal discharge (lochia rubra) is a normal finding during the first 4 days after birth.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents with accidental urine leakage during heavy lifting and occasional sudden strong urges to void, leading to moderate leakage. She denies changes in stool habits or pelvic pain. She has had three uneventful vaginal deliveries and is otherwise healthy. Examination shows no pelvic organ prolapse or neurological deficits. She is concerned about diminishing social activities due to fear of leakage.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence is marked by continuous dribbling due to incomplete bladder emptying, often with hesitancy or weak stream. This patient’s leakage occurs with exertion and urgency, not continuous dribbling, and lacks symptoms of incomplete emptying or voiding difficulties.

B) CORRECT:

Mixed incontinence manifests with symptoms of both stress and urge incontinence. This patient experiences urine leakage during physical exertion, indicative of stress incontinence, and sudden, strong urges to void, consistent with urge incontinence. Multiparity can weaken pelvic floor support, leading to urethral hypermobility and stress incontinence. Additionally, involuntary detrusor contractions cause urgency and leakage, characteristic of urge incontinence. The coexistence of these mechanisms supports the diagnosis of mixed incontinence.

Key learning point: Mixed incontinence is characterized by symptoms of both stress and urge incontinence, involving involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure and with a strong urge to void.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence involves urine leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as heavy lifting, without urgency. This patient also reports sudden, strong urges to void, indicating detrusor overactivity. The presence of urgency suggests a component beyond stress incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence is characterized by sudden, strong urges to void and leakage independent of physical exertion. This patient also experiences leakage during heavy lifting, suggesting urethral hypermobility and pelvic floor weakness, which are not typical of isolated urge incontinence.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents to the clinic with three months of suddenly feeling an overwhelming need to urinate. She is unable to reach the bathroom before losing a small amount of urine each time. These episodes are not preceded by coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavy objects. Examination shows no evidence of pelvic organ prolapse.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Overflow incontinence is characterized by involuntary urine leakage due to incomplete bladder emptying, often from an underactive detrusor or obstruction. It typically presents with gradual dribbling, not a sudden urge to void. The patient's symptoms suggest detrusor overactivity rather than urinary retention.

B) INCORRECT:

Functional incontinence occurs when physical or cognitive impairments prevent timely bathroom access, not due to urinary tract abnormalities. The patient's sudden urge to void and lack of mobility or cognitive issues indicate bladder dysfunction, not functional incontinence.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence involves urine leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing or sneezing. It is associated with pelvic floor weakness. The absence of exertional triggers and pelvic organ prolapse in this patient makes stress incontinence unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Urge incontinence manifests with a sudden, intense urge to urinate, often leading to involuntary leakage if the bathroom is not reached in time. This condition results from involuntary detrusor muscle contractions due to bladder overactivity. The absence of triggers such as coughing or sneezing, which are associated with stress incontinence, and the lack of pelvic organ prolapse, support the diagnosis of urge incontinence. The neurogenic mechanism behind detrusor instability is central to this condition, distinguishing it from other types of urinary incontinence.

Key learning point: Urge incontinence is characterized by a sudden, intense urge to urinate and an inability to control micturition, often leading to leakage before reaching the toilet.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with a six-month history of frequent dribbling of urine and difficulty initiating urination. He reports no burning or strong urges but often feels his bladder is not fully empty. He has type 2 diabetes and reduced sensation in both feet. Physical examination shows a mildly distended bladder with no abnormal findings on external genital exam.
Which diagnosis best explains these urinary symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Functional incontinence involves urinary leakage due to barriers preventing timely toilet access, such as physical or cognitive limitations. The patient’s symptoms of hesitancy, dribbling, and incomplete bladder emptying, along with a distended bladder, indicate lower urinary tract dysfunction. There is no evidence of cognitive impairment or reduced mobility contributing to functional incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence is characterized by sudden, intense urges to void with involuntary leakage, linked to detrusor overactivity. The patient’s symptoms of difficulty initiating urination and incomplete bladder emptying do not align with the acute urge seen in urge incontinence. The mildly distended bladder and absence of a strong urge suggest impaired detrusor contractility rather than hyperactivity.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence involves urine leakage with increased abdominal pressure, such as coughing or sneezing. The patient does not report such triggers. Instead, he presents with difficulty initiating urination and incomplete bladder emptying, indicating an issue with bladder emptying. Diabetic neuropathy affecting bladder innervation suggests a neurogenic mechanism, distinct from the pelvic floor weakness seen in stress incontinence.

D) CORRECT:

Overflow incontinence manifests when the bladder is chronically overdistended due to inadequate emptying. Patients often experience difficulty initiating urination, a weak stream, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. Persistent dribbling occurs when bladder pressure exceeds urethral resistance. The absence of burning, urgency, or pain, along with palpable bladder distension, indicates urinary retention rather than an irritative process. Type 2 diabetes can lead to autonomic neuropathy, impairing detrusor muscle function and promoting retention and overflow. This combination of features aligns with the pathophysiology of overflow incontinence.

Key learning point: Overflow incontinence is characterized by frequent dribbling of urine, difficulty initiating urination, and a distended bladder after voiding, often due to bladder outlet obstruction or detrusor muscle underactivity.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents with a year of involuntary leakage of urine. She experiences sudden urges to void with involuntary leakage, as well as leakage with coughing and sneezing. She has had three vaginal deliveries. She has no significant medical history or current medications. Her BMI is 30. Pelvic examination reveals reduced pelvic floor muscle tone.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management to address her urinary symptoms?

choices.text: Pelvic floor muscle exercises and bladder retraining

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The midurethral sling procedure is a surgical treatment for stress urinary incontinence, typically reserved for cases unresponsive to conservative management. This patient has mixed incontinence, and initial management should focus on noninvasive interventions like pelvic floor exercises to optimize pelvic floor function.

B) CORRECT:

Mixed urinary incontinence, characterized by both stress and urgency components, is initially managed with conservative strategies. Pelvic floor muscle exercises strengthen the muscles supporting the bladder and urethra, reducing stress incontinence symptoms like leakage during coughing. Bladder retraining helps manage urgency by increasing the interval between voiding episodes. These non-pharmacological interventions address both components of mixed incontinence, have minimal adverse effects, and improve quality of life.

Key learning point: For mixed urinary incontinence with reduced pelvic floor muscle strength, the first-line management includes pelvic floor exercises and bladder retraining to improve muscle control and manage urgency.

C) INCORRECT:

Anticholinergic medications reduce urgency by preventing detrusor overactivity, beneficial in pure urge incontinence. However, this patient also has stress incontinence symptoms, such as leakage with coughing, due to pelvic floor weakness. Initial management should focus on pelvic floor exercises and behavioral modifications, which address both stress and urgency components.

D) INCORRECT:

Vaginal pessaries provide mechanical support for pelvic organ prolapse and may help stress incontinence with significant prolapse. This patient has mixed incontinence without prolapse. Initial management should focus on pelvic floor exercises and bladder retraining, addressing both stress and urgency components.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old G3P3 woman presents with involuntary leakage of small amounts of urine when she exercises or sneezes for the last six months. She denies frequency, urgency, or dysuria. She has no other significant medical history. A standing cough test reproduces the leakage. Pelvic exam shows normal sensation and no masses. Post-void residual volume is 20 mL.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The midurethral sling procedure is a surgical treatment for stress urinary incontinence, typically considered after conservative measures have failed.

B) INCORRECT:
